content.rendered:
Để cải thiện kỹ năng đọc nhằm chuẩn bị tốt cho kỳ thi IELTS, các bạn hãy luyện tập qua Cambridge IELTS 19 – Test 1: Reading Passage 2 – The pirates of the ancient Mediterranean nhé!

A. Bài đọc The pirates of the ancient Mediterranean

The pirates of the ancient Mediterranean

The Mediterranean Sea has been a crossroads of civilizations for thousands of years, and piracy has been a constant presence throughout its history. From the ancient Phoenicians to the modern era, pirates have operated in these waters, preying on merchant ships and coastal settlements.

In ancient times, piracy was often indistinguishable from legitimate maritime trade and warfare. Many seafaring peoples, including the Phoenicians, Greeks, and Romans, engaged in what we would now consider piracy. The line between merchant, warrior, and pirate was often blurred, as ships would carry both goods and weapons, and crews would switch between trading and raiding depending on circumstances.

The ancient Greeks were particularly known for their maritime activities, and piracy was a common practice among many Greek city-states. The island of Crete, for example, was a notorious base for pirates who preyed on ships traveling between Greece and Egypt. The famous Greek hero Odysseus, in Homer's epic poem The Odyssey, encounters pirates and describes their activities in detail.

During the Roman Republic and Empire, piracy became a major problem that required military intervention. The Roman navy was established in part to combat piracy, and several major campaigns were launched against pirate strongholds. The most famous of these was Pompey's campaign against the Cilician pirates in 67 BCE, which resulted in the capture of thousands of pirates and the destruction of their bases.

Despite these efforts, piracy continued to flourish in the Mediterranean throughout the ancient period. The decline of the Roman Empire in the West led to a resurgence of piracy, as central authority weakened and maritime trade became more vulnerable. The Byzantine Empire, which succeeded Rome in the East, continued to struggle with piracy throughout its existence.

The medieval period saw the rise of new pirate groups, including the Barbary pirates of North Africa and the Christian corsairs of Malta and other Mediterranean islands. These groups operated with the tacit or explicit support of various states and continued the tradition of Mediterranean piracy well into the modern era.

Today, while piracy in the Mediterranean is much less common than in ancient times, the region's long history of maritime conflict and the strategic importance of its waters continue to make it an area of interest for naval powers and international organizations concerned with maritime security.
